results.title: Davey Jones Locker
results.description: Creating an alternative history by imagining that the children of African slaves thrown overboard during the Middle Passage built a technologically advanced underwater civilization beneath the Atlantic Ocean, Detroit’s Drexciya were one of the key Afrofuturist duos of the 1990s. Their mythology and worldbuilding inspired many artsts, musicians and filmmakers - and their hard hitting electro and techno beats spread this mythology on the dancefloor.
description_for_label: Creating an alternative history by imagining that the children of African slaves thrown overboard during the Middle Passage built a technologically advanced underwater civilization beneath the Atlantic Ocean, Detroit’s Drexciya were one of the key Afrofuturist duos of the 1990s. Their mythology and worldbuilding inspired many artsts, musicians and filmmakers - and their hard hitting electro and techno beats spread this mythology on the dancefloor.

results.title: Godzilla in gaming
results.material_description: Screen recordings of Snipe and Wib, Friday Night Arcade and MoviEVo's YouTube channels
results.brief_description: In the early 1980s, Godzilla stomped his way onto screens through retro gaming. Godzilla (C64) (1983) first gave players a pixelated monster’s view, smashing through cities. Then came Fierce Dragon Godzilla: Metropolis Destruction (1985), a Japan-only release where Godzilla unleashed havoc on urban landscapes. The Movie Monster Game (1986) let players choose from multiple kaiju, including Godzilla, to demolish cityscapes. In Godzilla vs. 3 Giant Monsters (1984), Godzilla took on three classic kaiju in turn-based battles, bringing strategic clashes to the gaming world. Each game added to the legend, expanding the King of the Monsters’ digital footprint.

results.title: Remixing Godzilla
results.material_description: Screen recordings of @gentlebl0ke (Moo Deng and Pesto), @phthartic5 (Roar), @ideatimes (Crab legs), @beeragon (Barbie), @jaydent.26 (Fashion)
results.brief_description: Seventy years ago, when the original Godzilla film was released no one had any idea of the global impact this monster would have. As the number of films in the Godzilla franchise has increased over the decades so has the number of fans and their devotion to the King of the Monsters. These clips are an example of the ways Godzilla is celebrated and re-invented by the fans - from a comparison of monster roars from across the franchise, a fashion call out for the Godzilla themed shoes worn by the team which won the first Oscar for a Godzilla film, and a fan mash up of Godzilla and Barbie.
results.description: Seventy years ago, when the original Godzilla film was released no one had any idea of the global impact this monster would have. As the number of films in the Godzilla franchise has increased over the decades so has the number of fans and their devotion to the King of the Monsters. These clips are an example of the ways Godzilla is celebrated and re-invented by the fans - from a comparison of monster roars from across the franchise, a fashion call out for the Godzilla-themed shoes worn by the cast of Godzilla Minus One, and a fan mash-up of Godzilla and Barbie.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

After his signature opening title, ‘Round About Alice’, Wallace goes to the desert landscape around Alice Springs, in the Northern Territory, including close-ups of wildflowers and distance shots of ‘Mount Conner’. We see Alice Springs streets and landmarks, and the annual (since 1970) ‘Alice Springs Lions Club Camel Cup’ race. Features the historic Alice Springs Telegraph Station (1872), once also the site of ‘The Bungalow’ school, (1932-1942) for children then identified by government as ‘part aboriginal’. Wallace then films in the dramatic landscape of the ‘McDonnell Ranges’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Round About Alice’, ‘A W.H.C film’.
00:01:10:00 classic Australian style windmill spinning in wind
00:01:14:00 Mount Conner in distance
00:03:26:00 Street scenes Alice Springs
00:03:47:00 John Flynn Memorial Church, Alice Springs, exterior and interior.
00:04:31:00 extended sequence of camel racing, including scenes of watching crowd, a Scottish pipe band, and particpants in fancy dress
00:07:21:00 night sequence with illumintaed ‘Lions Cup’ sign with outline of a camel in lihghts; fireworks
00:08:02:00 Anzac Hill War Memorial (dedicated 1934) at Alice Springs, followed by aerial views of the town
00:08:32:00 Alice Springs Telegraph Station buildings and surrounds
00:09:15:00 Gravestones in the Alice Springs Telegraph Station Cemetery
00:09:58:00 John Flynn gravesite memorial
00:10:19:00 Roadsign for Simpsons Gap followed by scenes of and in McDonnell Ranges, including camping activities.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane

results.title: Time changes
results.brief_description: “Time changes” is an experimental, self-reflexive film, comprised of footage filmed over four years by Sue Ford and her friends. Described by the artist as being “a documentary about time and change, focusing on four men who were filmmakers and close friends”, the film features friends Stuart Green, Chris Maudson, John Phillips and Paul Reed, as well as Ford, her children Emma and Ben, and artists Richard Brennan, Bonita Ely, Margo Nash and Ashe Venn. Through unscripted dialogue, the friends’ conversations range across topics such as the integrity of filmmaking and creative practice to ways of living and relationships.
results.description: Time changes is an experimental, self-reflexive film, comprised of footage filmed over four years by Sue Ford and her friends. Through unscripted dialogue, the friends’ conversations range across topics such as the integrity of filmmaking and creative practice to ways of living and relationships.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip along the ‘Great Ocean Road’ in Victoria. The Great Ocean Road is an Australian National Heritage listed 243 kilometres stretch of road along the south-eastern coast of Victoria between Torquay and Allansford near Warrnambool. The film features many scenes of the ocean, coastal walks, rock formations such as the Twelve Apostles, and seaside towns.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Ocean Road’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:01:01:00 woman walking down a path from the lighthouse at Airey’s Inlet
00:01:14:00 the historic ‘Great Ocean Road’ sign over the highway
00:01:27:00 sign for ‘Cinema Point lookout’ with vintage car in foreground
00:05:06:00 the Twelve Apostles
00:09:20:00 two people at a lookout
00:12:00:00 woman lying on the ground with a camera
00:14:50:00 boats in a bay
00:16:31:00 a small harbour
00:17:38:00 a bluestone church, likely St John’s in Port Fairy
00:017:57:00 the Yambuk Inn in Port Fairy
00:19:42:00 an emu running down the road
00:19:57:00 two women comparing sticks for walking
00:23:42:00 a jetty by a river
00:24:40:00 sunset over the water
00:25:01:00 title card ‘The End’
results.description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip along the ‘Great Ocean Road’ in Victoria. The Great Ocean Road is an Australian National Heritage listed 243 kilometres stretch of road along the south-eastern coast of Victoria between Torquay and Allansford near Warrnambool. The film features many scenes of the ocean, coastal walks, rock formations such as the Twelve Apostles, and seaside towns.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Ocean Road’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:01:01:00 woman walking down a path from the lighthouse at Airey’s Inlet
00:01:14:00 the historic ‘Great Ocean Road’ sign over the highway
00:01:27:00 sign for ‘Cinema Point lookout’ with vintage car in foreground
00:05:06:00 the Twelve Apostles
00:09:20:00 two people at a lookout
00:12:00:00 woman lying on the ground with a camera
00:14:50:00 boats in a bay
00:16:31:00 a small harbour
00:17:38:00 a bluestone church, likely St John’s in Port Fairy
00:017:57:00 the Yambuk Inn in Port Fairy
00:19:42:00 an emu running down the road
00:19:57:00 two women comparing sticks for walking
00:23:42:00 a jetty by a river
00:24:40:00 sunset over the water
00:25:01:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:27:00 fishing boats by the sea
00:02:05:00 group of women sitting around talking
00:03:19:00 young child
00:04:21:00 boats in the bay
00:05:21:00 sign for ‘Boumana War Cemetery’
00:06:45:00 views across a valley
00:07:04:00 a waterfall
00:09:05:00 men in headdresses
00:09:16:00 a polo game with locals watching
00:10:57:00 views over the bay
00:12:44:00 girls playing a ball game
00:13:15:00 man fixing a small boat
00:14:00:00 a traffic warden in the middle of an intersection
00:15:16:00 views from an aeroplane

results.title: [Around Australia with Movietone; Gt. Barrier Reef; Sporting Highlights; Skiing; 1949 Melbourne Cup]

video_links.name: [Around Australia with Movietone; Gt. Barrier Reef; Sporting Highlights; Skiing; 1949 Melbourne Cup]

results.brief_description:
This film is a Movietone Newsreel, a theatrical news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. This newsreel consists of five sections, covering news and events around Australia in 1949.

The first section, titled ‘Around Australia with Movietone’, photographed by J. W. Trerise shows pearl divers in Darwin, Northern Territory. The film takes place on a Japanese lugger, featuring Japanese divers and Peter Nakashiba, an interpreter and advisor to the Japanese in Darwin. It shows the protective diving suits and apparatus worn by pearl divers.

The second section is titled ‘Gt Barrier Reef’ and shows people fishing from trawlers on the Great Barrier Reef. The narrator describes the fishing as a popular sport and names the type of fish, including Spanish mackerel.

In the third section, ‘Sporting Highlights’, we see a horse rodeo in Warwick, Queensland, with commentary by Jack Davey, a popular radio entertainer who narrated Movietone News reels from the 1930s to 1950s.

The fourth section is titled ‘Skiing’, and takes place at Mount Kosciuszko, showing the ski fields and resort as a popular tourist destination. It includes footage of George Day, the manager of the Chalet at Charlotte Pass and a renowned Australian skier.

The final section, titled ‘1949 Melbourne Cup’, shows the popular horse racing event at Flemington Race Course, Melbourne, which in 1949 was won by Foxzami.
results.title_for_label: [Around Australia with Movietone; Gt. Barrier Reef; Sporting Highlights; Skiing; 1949 Melbourne Cup]
